newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian base metals steady on low volumes.
newsitem.headline: Indian base metals steady on low volumes.

text.p: Indian metals' prices were steady on Tuesday but trading volumes were low with many traders absent because of the Hindu kite festival, dealers said.
The kite festival is celebrated on Tuesday.

Ready copper was steady at 12,550 rupees per quintal. It was up by 150 rupees last week. "Sentiment is firm on reports of rising global prices," said Sharad Parikh, president of the Bombay Metal Exchange.
Tin was steady at 34,500 rupees and nickel at 36,800 rupees per quintal. Last week tin was up by 200 rupees and nickel was up by 600 rupees.
Aluminium was quoted at the last level of 7,200 rupees per quintal. So was zinc at 6,500 rupees and lead at 4,400 rupees.
Activity was also low as some traders were awaiting the new selling prices by state-owned agencies for the second half of this month. "I am not expecting major changes in these prices," Parikh said.
